text: An orrery is a mechanical model of the Solar System. It shows the relative positions and motions of the planets and moons. It is usually a heliocentric model.King, Henry C. & Millburn, John R. 1978. Geared to the stars : the evolution of planetariums, orreries, and astronomical clocks. Toronto: University of Toronto Press. pp. 28–41. The Greeks had working planetaria. The first orrery that was a planetarium of the modern era was produced in 1704.Calvert, H.R. 1967. Astronomy: globes, orreries and other models. London: H.M.S.O. One was presented to Charles Boyle, 4th Earl of Orrery – hence the name. They are usually driven by a clockwork mechanism. The globe in the centre represents the Sun, and a planet is at the end of each arm. The first known orrery was the Antikythera mechanism, variously dated from 60 to 150 BC. == References == Category:Scientific modeling Category:Machines Category:1704
